lg.l: Whether 1A large old house two miles from Sr A A's seat Hamiltons bawn shall be turned into a Malt-house or a Barack.
Septr 08. 2d 1728
Thus spoke to my Lady, the Knight full of care;
Let me have your advice in a weighty affair.This Hamilton's 1asterisk references the same note as FN1 bawn, while it sticks on my hand,
I lose by the house what I get by the land.
But, how to dispose of it to the best bidder,
For a Barack or malt-house, we now must consider.First, let me suppose, I make it a malt-house:
Here, I have computed the profit will fall t' us:
There's nine hundred pounds for labor and grain;
I encrease it to twelve: so three hundred remain.
A handsom addition for wine and good chear;
Three dishes a day, and three hogsheads a year.
With a dozen large vessels my vault shall be stor'd,
No little scrub joynt shall come on my board:
And you and the Dean no more shall combine
To stint me at night to one bottle of wine;
Nor shall I for his humor permit you to purloyn
A stone and a half of goodbief from my surloyn.If I make it a Barrack, the Crown is my tenant.
My dear, I have ponder'd again and again on't.
In poundage and draw-backs I lose half my rent,
And, whatever they give me, I must be content,Or joyn with the Court in evry debate;
And rather than that, I would lose my estate.Thus ended the Knight: Thus began his meek wife.
It must, and it shall be a Barrack, my life.
I'm grown a meer Mopus; no company comes,
But a rabble of tenants, and rusty dull 2A cant word in Ireland for a poor country Clergyman. Rums.
With Parsons what Lady can keep her self clean?
I'm all over dawb'd when I sit by the Dean.
But, if you will give us a Barrack, my dear,
The Captain, I'm sure, will allways come here:
I then shall not value his Dean-ship a straw,
For, the Captain, I warrant, will keep him in aw;
Or, should he pretend to be brisk and alert
Will tell him, that Chaplains must not be so pert:
That, men of his coat should be minding their pray'rs,
And, not among ladyes to give themselves airs.Thus argu'd my lady, but argu'd in vain:
The Knight his opinion resolv'd to maintain.But, 3My Lady's waiting-woman.Hannah who listened to all that had pass't,
And, could not endure so vulgar a tast;
As soon as her Ladyship call'd to be dress't,
“Cry'd, Madam; why sure my Master's possess't.
“Sr Arthur the Malster! del·how fine it will sound?
“I'd rather the Bawn were sunk under ground.
“But, Madam, I guesst there would never come good
“When I saw him so often with 4Two of Sr A A's managersDarby and Wood.
“And now my dream's out: for I was a-dream'd
“That I saw a huge rat; O dear, how I scream'd!
“And after, methought I lost my new shoes;
“And, Molly, she said I should hear some ill news.“Dear Madam, had you but the Spirit to teaze,
“&c·You might have a Barrack whenever you please.
And Madam, I always believ'd you so stout,
That for twenty denyals you would not give out.
If I had a husband like him, I purtest,
Till he gave me my will, I would give him no rest:
And, rather than come in the same pair of sheets
With such a cross man, I would lye in the streets.
But Madam I beg you contrive and invent,
And worry him out till he gives his consent.Dear Madam, when e'er of a Barrack I think,
An I were to be hang'd I can't sleep a wink
For, if a new crotchet comes into my brain,
I can't get it out though I'd never so fain.
I fancy already a Barrack contriv'd
At Hamilton's bawn, and the troop is arriv'd.
Of this, to be sure SrArthur has warning,
And waits on the Captain betimes the next morning.Now, see, when they meet, how their Honors behave,
Noble Captain, Your Servant────SrArthur, Your Slave────
You honor me much────The honor is mine────
`Twas a sad rainy night────but the morning is fine────
Pray, how does my Lady?────My wife's at your service────
I think I have seen her picture by Iervis────
Good morrow good Captain──────I'll wait on you down────
You sha'n't stir a foot────You'll think me a-clown────
For all the world Captain, not half an inch farther────
You must be obeyd: Your Servant SrArthur,
My humble respects to my Lady unknown──────
I hope you will use my house as your own.prate.
Thou hast certainly gotten add·a cup in thy pate.add·Pray Madam be quiet. What was it I said.──
You had like to have put it quite out of my headNext day to be sure, the Captain will come
At the head of his troop with trumpet and drum;
Now Madam, observe how he marches in state;
The man with the kettel-drum enters the gate:
Dub dub a dub dub. The trumpeters follow
Tantara, tantara, while all the boys hollow.
See, now comes the Captain all dawb'd with gold lace:
O law, the sweet gentleman; look in his face:
And see how he rides like a lord of the land
With the fine flaming Sword that he holds in his hand:
And, his horse, the dear Creter, it prances and rears
With ribbins in knots at it's tail and it's ears.
At last comes the troop, by the word of command
When Drawn up in our court, tillwhencaretwhenWhen the Captain cryes, STAND.
Your Ladyship lifts up the sash to be seen;
(For sure, I had dizen'd you out like a Queen)
The Captain, to show he is proud of the favor,
Looks up to your window, and cocks up his beaver.
(His beaver is cockt: pray Madam, mark that:
For, a Captain of horse never takes off his hat;
Because he has never a hand that is idle;
For, the right holds his sword, and the left holds his bridle)
Then, flourishes thrice his sword in the air
As a compliment due to a lady so fair.
How I tremble to think of the blood it hath spilt!
Then, he low'rs down the point, and kisses the hilt.
Your Ladyship smiles, and thus you begin;
Pray Captain be pleas'd to light and walk in.
The Captain salutes you with congee profound;
And your Ladyship curchyes half way to the ground.del illegible word·Kitt; run to Your master, and bid him come to us,
I'm sure he'll be proud of the honor you do us.
And, Captain, you'll do us the favor to stay,
And take a short dinner here with us to day.
You're heartily welcome. But as for good chear,
You come in the very worst time of the year.
If I had but expected so worthy a guest────
Lord! Madam! your Ladyship sure is in jest.
You banter me, Madam, the Kingdom must grant──────
You Officers, Captain, are so complaisant.──Hist Huzzy I think I hear some body coming──
No Madam; tis onely SrArthur a humming.To shorten my tale (for, I hate a long story)
The Captain at dinner appears in his glory.
The Dean and the 5Doctor Jenny, a ?·Clergy-man at Armagh.Doctor have humbled their pride;
For, the Captain's entreated to sit by your side.
And, because he's their betters, you carve for him first;
The Parsons for envy are ready to burst.
The servants amazd, are scarce ever able
To keep off their eyes as they wait at the table.
And, Molly and I have thrust in our nose
To peep on the Captain in all his fine cloze.
Dear Madam, be sure, he's a fine-spoken man;
Do but hear, on the clergymen how his tongue ran.
And, Madam says he, if such dinners you give,
You'll never want Parsons as long as you live.
I ne'r knew a Parson without a good nose;
But, the Devil's as welcom wherever he goes.
G──d──me, they bid us reform, and repent;
But, Z────s by their looks they never keep lLent.MisterCurate, for all your grave looks, I'm afraid,
You cast a Sheep's eye on her Ladyship's mayd:
I wish she would lend you her pretty white hand
In mending your gown, and smoothing your band.
(For, the Dean was so shabby, and lookt like a Ninny,
That, the Captain suppos'd he was Coverwriting curate to Iinny.)Whenever you seeadd caret, then delbuta Cassock and gown,
A hundred to one it add.caret·but·it covers a clown
Observe how a Parson comes into a room
G──d──me he hobbles as bad as my groom
A Scholard when just from his college broke loose
Can hardly tell how to cry Bo to a goose.
Your Noved's and Blutracks, and Omurs, and stuff,
By G──they don't signify this pinch of Snuff.To give a young gentleman del·good·add right education
The army's the onely good School in the Nation
My Schoolmaster call'd me a dunce and a fool
But, at cuffs I was always the Cock of the School.
I never could take to my book for the blood o' me
And the puppy confesst, he expected no good o' me.
Now, Madam you'll think it a strange thing to say;
But, the Sight of a book makes me sick to this day.Never since I was born did I hear so much wit:
And, Madam I laugh'd till I thought I should split:
So, then you lookt scornfull, and snifft at the Dean,
As, who should say; NOW, am aI6Nick-names for my Lady.Skinny and Lean?
But, he durst not so much as once open his lips.
And, the Doctor was plaguily down in the HippsThus, merciless Hannah ran on in her talk,
Till she heard the Dean call; Will your Ladyship walk?
Her Ladyship answers, I'm just coming down.
Then, turning to Hannah, and forcing a frown;
Although it was plain, as in her heart she was glad;
Cry'd, Huzzy; Why sure the wench is gone mad.
How could these Chimeraes get into your brains?────
Come hither, and take this old gown for your pains.
But, the Dean, if this secret should come to his ears,
Will never have done with his gibes and his jears.
For your life, not a word of the matter, I charge ye:
Give me but a Barrack, a fig for the Clergy.866-271R
